quotes.cite: Amy Skylark Foster Gillies; Michael Steven Buble; Alan Pei Jei Chang
quotes.quote: Let me go home / I'm just too far / From where you are / I wanna come home

quotes.cite: Amy Skylark Foster Gillies; Michael Steven Buble; Alan Pei Jei Chang
quotes.quote: And I'm surrounded by / A million people I / I still feel alone / Oh, let me go home / Oh, I miss you, you know
Homeward bound / I wish I was / Homeward bound / Home where my thought's escapin' / Home where my music's playin' / Home where my love lies waitin' / Silently for me
And I quite miss home / And I miss you telling me / To leave my shoes at the door / 'Cause you just swept the floor / And the dirt drives you crazy
Yeah, I quite miss home / 'Cause it feels like poetry / When the rain falls down on the window / While you're in my arms / And we're watching the TV
Ah, it's been so long since I began to roam / Thought I'd make it on my own / All I wanna do is go home
Been so long since, I began to roam / Never should have left home / Thought I was grown / But now I see what it meant to me

quotes.cite: Mick Hucknall; Peter Lewinson; Steve Lewinson
quotes.quote: So fake cool image should be over / Cause I long for a feeling of home / Real life, depicted in song / A loving memory / After long, home is a place where I yearn to belong

quotes.cite: Bill Danoff; John Denver; Taffy Nivert Danoff
quotes.quote: Country roads, take me home / To the place I belong / West Virginia, mountain mama / Take me home, country roads

quotes.cite: Bill Danoff; John Denver; Taffy Nivert Danoff
quotes.quote: I hear her voice in the mornin' hour, she calls me / The radio reminds me of my home far away / Drivin' down the road, I get a feelin' / That I should've been home yesterday, yesterday
If I could walk around I swear I'll leave / Won't take nothing but a memory / From the house that built me
I hear a heart that's sound and high, / I hear the heart within me cry: / 'I'm homesick for my hills again — / My hills again! / Cotswold or Malvern, sun or rain! / My hills again!'

How sweet 'tis to sit 'neath a fond father's smile, / And the caress of a mother to soothe and beguile! / Let others delight mid new pleasures to roam, / But give me, oh, give me, the pleasures of home. / Home, home, sweet, sweet home! / There's no place like home, oh, there's no place like home!

Home along, home along, an' I'd like to see it now, / The ruddy furrow white wi' gulls behind my father's plough — / A friend to greet, an' a girl to meet, an' a score o' folks to see, / Home along, home along, in the West Countrie!

We must get home — for we have been away / So long it seems forever and a day! / And O so very homesick we have grown, / The laughter of the world is like a moan / In our tired hearing, and its songs as vain, — / We must get home — we must get home again!
My home, my home, my cottage home, / Thou fair and lovely spot, / How sad and lonely is my soul, / When I can view thee not;
He moans in his slumber 'Why did I ever / So far — westwardly roam; / Oh, must I lie down must I sleep forever / With no loving letters from home?'
Anyhow / I've poetry and music too to-day / in the very clatter: it goes 'Home, home, home.'

The universe wears a smiling face / As you spill your talk of the old home place; / You talk of the streets, and the home town jokes, / And you find that you know each other's folks; / And you haven't any more woes at all / And you both decide that the world is small — / A statement adding to its renown / When you meet a man from your own home town.
Mid pleasures and palaces though we may roam, / Be it ever so humble, there's no place like home.
Keep the Home-fires burning, / While your hearts are yearning, / Though your lads are far away / They dream of Home.

Perhaps the self-same song that found a path / Through the sad heart of Ruth, when, sick for home, / She stood in tears amid the alien corn; / The same that oft-times hath / Charmed magic casements, opening on the foam / Of perilous seas, in faery lands forlorn.
Home, sweet home.
Better is the smoke of my own house than the fire of another's.
I would rather see smoke from my own chimney than the fire on another's hearth.
Sooner or later we hasten to one home.
Travel east or travel west, a man's own home is still the best.
Home is the strangest of common places, / Drenched with the light of familiar faces.
Ever before us is home's immensity, / Always within us its sheer intensity.

When we are young and restless to be free, home is the place from which we long to escape. But if there is still a home intact when trouble arises and life becomes a battlefield, home is the place to which we yearn to return.
